title: Has artificial intelligence surpass the power of the human brain? - Quora

response.answer_text: AI and the human brain operate so differently that it is almost pointless to compare them. For example, to train a neural network to tell if a photo is a cat or a dog it will need to have thousands of photos fed through it. But a child knows the difference with only a few hundred (or even less) exemplars. Humans are very good at holding on to ideas that are in direct conflict. Algorithms not so much. AI can’t tell the difference between true and false data without being explicitly trained on that data class. And even then it is only partitioning the data, not thinking about truth. A neural network can be trained on data that humans can’t even “load” into their brains. No human can process a list of millions of items, especially when the variables are abstractions. Deep Learning does this all the time. Will AI ever surpass humans across all problem domains? I suspect that we will be getting close to that point when AI starts to exhibit the machine version of mental illness. I say this un-ironically. AI that has the complexity and richness of human experience will almost certainly have fluctuating “mental states”, some that are substantially less functional than others. So to answer your question - yes or no depends entirely on the task at hand.
only in extremely limited situations, where there are a small number of variables and calculation speed counts. even the best chess computer would be a total moron at almost everything else.

Can AI feel the love of a parent for a newborn,see and feel he empathy for an starving orphan child in a war torn country? There is your answer. It may do calculations faster and better but lacks what every human is born with.
